questions.question_text: An alert has been distributed throughout the information security community regarding a critical Apache vulnerability. Which of the following courses of action would ONLY identify the known vulnerability?

discussion.content: This question was in the exam :)

Answer is B
Similar Q in 002
This is a tricky question. And re-reading it again many times, I think this is B. Question only asks the action that would ONLY identify the known vulnerability.
An Apache server is a specific type of Linux distribution. Running the scan for the vulnerability that only affects this type of server will be most efficient. Answer B
I think the problem with C and D is that you’d possibly still find other vulnerabilities. But the question specified only targeting this vuln.
Can also be C? Can anyone verify?

I think this is D. Performing a scan for a specific vulnerability might not see the apache if it can only be seen via authenticated scanning. Letter B doesn't even say what kind of scan it would perform.

comments.content: Its said in the answer, scan for the specific vulnerability on all web servers. Besides you can determine its apache even its not authenticated scan, auth scan are focused on priv escalation and services that needed creds, you can verify this by using nessus authenticated scan

choices.D: Perform an authenticated scan on all web servers in the environment.
choices.C: Perform a web vulnerability scan on all servers in the environment.
choices.A: Perform an unauthenticated vulnerability scan on all servers in the environment.
choices.B: Perform a scan for the specific vulnerability on all web servers.

questions.question_text: Which of the following commands would a security analyst use to make a copy of an image for forensics use?

discussion.content: This question was in the exam :)
Answer A. A gift in the exam. Also in 002

questions.question_text: As part of an upcoming engagement for a client, an analyst is configuring a penetration testing application to ensure the scan complies with information defined in the SOW. Which of the following types of information should be considered based on information traditionally found in the SOW? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: This may actually be A & B: https://www.triaxiomsecurity.com/2019/06/03/what-to-look-for-in-a-penetration-testing-statement-of-work/

comments.content: Nope. Answers are correct. SOW would define deliverables like what final docs would be received. It won’t define the contents of those docs.

choices.B: Contents of the executive summary report

questions.question_text:
An HR employee began having issues with a device becoming unresponsive after attempting to open an email attachment. When informed, the security analyst became suspicious of the situation, even though there was not any unusual behavior on the IDS or any alerts from the antivirus software. Which of the following
BEST describes the type of threat in this situation?

discussion.content:
though there was not any unusual behavior on the IDS 
Zero day Malware

questions.question_text: An organization wants to remediate vulnerabilities associated with its web servers. An initial vulnerability scan has been performed, and analysts are reviewing the results. Before starting any remediation, the analysts want to remove false positives to avoid spending time on issues that are not actual vulnerabilities. Which of the following would be an indicator of a likely false positive?

discussion.content: I think it should be C. Version mismatch could indicate false positives.

comments.content:
Quick extra comment here: https://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/en/SSKMKU/com.ibm.qradar.doc/c_qvm_false_positive_vulns.html

Often vulnerability scanners rely on banner grabbing to determine service versions.

discussion.content:
This can only be C.

A. Compliance testing != Vulnerability scanning, so not A.
B. Items marked as LOW are NOT necessarily informational only. Criticality has nothing to do with accuracy! So not B.
C. The detected version of an application may indeed differ from that of an Automated Asset Inventory, especially if said inventory was built with locally installed agents. So C.
D. Just because something is encrypted doesn't mean it isn't vulnerable.
Letter B - B. Any items labeled ‘low’ are considered informational only. - this is not considered false positives since they are information gathered by the scanner.

comments.content:
Correcting myself. I think this is B.

A. This is wrong because scanner compliance plug-in is only used for compliance scanning (if the machine/device is compliant with specified configurations) and not being used to detect vulnerabilities
B. Any items labeled "˜low' are considered informational only - this is the only good choice that we have. Low severity vulnerabilities may be actual vulnerabilities, but their impact is negligible or its very hard to exploit them, the reason why they were tagged as low severity.
C. The scan result version is being compared to automated asset inventory (not previous scans)
D. "˜HTTPS' entries indicate the web page is encrypted securely, but doesn't mean that detected vulnerabilities are already false positives.

discussion.content: I think this is A. Outdated plugins would mean false positives.

choices.A: Reports show the scanner compliance plug-in is out-of-date.
choices.C: The scan result version is different from the automated asset inventory.
choices.B: Any items labeled "˜low' are considered informational only.
choices.D: "˜HTTPS' entries indicate the web page is encrypted securely.
